Macro Theme : US Growth & Business Cycle

US Growth & Business Cycle: synthesising capex, production, durables, housing and yield-curve signals.

As of 2025-12-16

Gemini Summary

Synthesising Fed liquidity, money supply, SOFR positioning and real-rate signals.

Executive Summary

The US monetary environment reflects a careful rebalancing by the Federal Reserve. Following a period of money market tightening, the FOMC has ceased balance sheet runoff and initiated targeted purchases of shorter-term Treasury securities to maintain ample reserves, suggesting a transition towards stabilizing liquidity conditions. While nominal Treasury yields are largely unchanged, real yields have shown a tendency to rise at short maturities due to decreased inflation compensation [Source: fomcminutes20251029]. The policy stance, after three successive rate cuts, is now considered to be within a broad range of estimates for its neutral value, indicating a "Near neutral" posture [Source: powell_pc_20251210]. However, there is no clear consensus on the directional drift of this neutral rate among participants [Source: powell_pc_20251210]. The overall monetary tone is one of careful balance, with liquidity support aimed at maintaining market function alongside a policy rate assessed as near neutral.

  • Fed liquidity condition: Stabilising with targeted support
  • M2 regime: (No data)
  • Real-rate regime: Elevated / Near Neutral (from policy stance vs. r* and rising short-term real yields)
  • Neutral Rate (r*) stance: NEAR NEUTRAL [Source: powell_pc_20251210]
  • Neutral Rate (r*) drift: UNCLEAR [Source: powell_pc_20251210]
  • SOFR positioning tone: (No data)
  • Overall monetary tone: Balancing / Gradually Stabilising

1. Federal Reserve Liquidity Dynamics

Money market conditions have experienced tightening, as evidenced by repo rates increasing relative to administered rates and the effective federal funds rate (EFFR rising relative to the interest rate on reserve balances (IORB)). In response, the Federal Reserve has adjusted its balance sheet policy, ceasing runoff as of December 1, with reinvestments redirected to shorter-term Treasury bills [Source: monetary20251029a]. Concurrently, the FOMC has initiated purchases of shorter-term Treasury securities in December to maintain ample reserve levels, indicating a shift towards providing targeted liquidity support. These actions classify the current liquidity environment as stabilizing, with proactive measures taken to prevent further tightening and ensure market functionality [Source: monetary20251210a].

2. Money Supply (M2)

Information regarding the M2 money supply signal and its regime classification is not available in the provided context. Therefore, no assessment of money supply dynamics can be furnished.

3. Real Interest Rates, Neutral Rate (r*) & Policy Expectations

Nominal Treasury yields have shown limited change in the recent period. However, real yields have registered a modest increase at shorter maturities, primarily attributable to a decrease in inflation compensation [Source: fomcminutes20251029]. This upward movement in short-term real yields implies a tendency towards greater restrictiveness in the real rate environment.

The policy stance relative to the neutral rate (r*) is currently assessed as NEAR NEUTRAL. This follows three successive federal funds rate cuts, totaling 75 basis points, which have moved the target range to 3.5-3.75 percent. This adjusted policy rate is now considered by the FOMC to be within a "broad range of estimates of its neutral value" [Source: powell_pc_20251210]. Regarding the directional drift of the neutral rate estimate, there is no clear consensus among participants [Source: powell_pc_20251210]. The confidence in this assessment is not explicitly stated in citable documents.

Specifics regarding SOFR futures positioning (3-month and 5-year) are not available in the provided materials. Therefore, an analysis of speculative versus hedger positioning and their implications for near-term or medium-term policy expectations cannot be conducted.

4. Synthesised Monetary Regime

The synthesised monetary regime is characterized by a transition towards a more balanced stance. Federal Reserve liquidity policy has shifted from active draining to targeted support, aimed at maintaining ample reserves and market functioning after a period of money market tightening [Source: monetary20251210a], [Source: monetary20251029a]. Concurrently, the policy real interest rate is assessed as near neutral, following recent rate cuts [Source: powell_pc_20251210]. While short-term real yields have shown some upward pressure, the overall policy posture aims to be neither restrictive nor accommodative relative to estimated neutral conditions.

Pillar Current Regime Interpretation
Fed Liquidity Stabilising with Targeted Support Cessation of balance sheet runoff and initiation of short-term Treasury purchases to maintain ample reserves following money market tightening.
M2 Money Supply (No data) No available data for M2 growth or regime classification.
Real Rates Elevated / Near Neutral Short-term real yields are rising due to decreased inflation compensation; policy stance is near the estimated neutral rate.
Neutral Rate (r*) Context Near Neutral Stance / Unclear Drift Policy stance is within a broad range of its neutral value; no consensus on r* directional drift [Source: powell_pc_20251210].
SOFR Policy Expectations (No data) No available SOFR positioning data for policy expectations.

5. Forward Risks

Easing / Supportive Risks

  • Persistently positive liquidity impulse (e.g., more aggressive reserve maintenance, further shifts in reinvestment policy)
  • Stabilising or falling real yields from current elevated levels
  • Policy stance drifting towards accommodative relative to neutral (r*) (if indicated by future data)

Tightening / Reversal Risks

  • Renewed increase in real yields above trend, particularly at longer maturities
  • Reversal in money market dynamics leading to renewed liquidity drain without Fed intervention
  • Policy stance remaining or becoming more restrictive vs neutral (r*) (if indicated by future data or a rising r* consensus)

6. Investment Interpretation (Informational)

The current monetary regime, characterized by a near-neutral policy stance and active liquidity management by the Federal Reserve, implies generally stable but not exceptionally loose funding conditions. Liquidity premia are likely influenced by the ongoing targeted support, which aims to prevent undue market stress, but also by the earlier money market tightening. Market access is expected to remain orderly, reflecting the Fed's proactive efforts to maintain ample reserves.

In this environment, valuation sensitivity across rates, credit, and risk assets is likely balanced. A near-neutral policy stance typically limits significant re-rating potential driven solely by monetary policy, suggesting that market movements will be more attuned to fundamental growth and earnings dynamics. Credit spreads may reflect underlying economic conditions and credit quality more directly, while risk assets could exhibit sensitivity to any shifts in growth expectations or renewed inflation concerns, particularly given the observed increase in short-term real yields [Source: fomcminutes20251029]. The absence of strong directional signals from money supply or SOFR positioning implies a lack of explicit monetary tailwinds or headwinds from those channels, placing greater emphasis on macro fundamentals.
